"How about that we should try to be sensitive to others' feelings before using certain terms. Is it possible to mostly agree with that?"

Nope. Appealing to "hurt feelings" are the left's favourite method of stifling dissent to their narrative.

In complete agreement with Professor Ravitch. She is one of the few educators in the US willing to look back at systems that fail and to determine WHY they have failed. The inequity in the socio-economic status of students and families is the greatest factor. Until those factors are changed and we are willing to work separately with second language English learners, no progress will be made in the US education system. Mainstreaming has great social value but only if students have the skills to participate readily in learning with their peers. We have become a test-driven nation to the detriment of learning.

Bad parenting is problematic. As a society blaming their parents, though, leaves us with poorly educated children who cost more than it would have to educate them well in the first place.
Every parent should have access to high quality day care at any time, whether they need to work, go to school, or just need a sanity break. While in day care they could learn the basics they need to succeed.
Pre kindergarten is too little too late.

While I agree that testing wastes enormous time and resources, while not yielding valid measures of student achievement, parents who complain about it bear some share of responsibility.
At least, parents who rushed to buy their kids calculators and insisted that schools allow their use, should recognize that having "hated math" is no excuse for failing to help your children to learn it.
If you had sat down with them and made them memorize their math tables, which are the basis of all math learning, no one would have thought we needed anything as complex and over-thought as Common Core. Same goes for reading to your children and having books in the house instead of allowing them unlimited TV.

"...we would give teachers the autonomy to tailor instruction to meet the needs of the children in front of them and to write their own tests."

This proscription is a recipe for making inequality worse... as more motivated students from families that encourage learning would leapfrog the less "privileged" ones.

Recent studies show that the only approach to reduce inequality is to start pre-kindergarten, as kids who start late can never catch up. Ultimately, however, this is the question of culture gaps. Well intentions do not a culture change.

Then-Secretary of Education Arne Duncan put on the full court press to get Diane Ravitch, America's most respected education scholar, to support the Common Core. She reserved the right to make up her own mind based on the evidence. She decided that she was against it, and she has even taken the more radical position that she is against the idea of national education standards.

As a parent with children in public education, I thank Diane Ravitch from the bottom of my heart.

Yes, I taught at a vocational high school with automotive, air conditioning and refrigeration, electrician, plumber, computer aided design, and food services. These are all high paying jobs, that can't be outsourced to another country, and training in them gives experience in reading and writing technical material, math, science, etc.
The school has been under attack by the state and city since I started working there in 2002, and is now 20% of its size then, with less equipment.

The standards are "College & Career Ready" not "College Ready." Nearly every career that provides a family sustaining wage in this country requires at least 1 year of post-secondary education/training. Some of the largest providers of this training are Community Colleges. The community colleges in my area provides training in the areas you mentioned often in partnership with regional employers and trade union apprenticeship programs.  College is not  synonymous with a 4-year liberal arts degree.

Indeed, the Common Core Standards fall short in that they do not take into account English Language learners or students with learning disabilities. This must be corrected.

The deeper problem lies in the adoption of national standards that assume that all American children can and should be made "college ready." College readiness ignores those students and young adult who want, would benefit from and acheive success in vocational training in the building trades, landscaping, hospitality and restaurant industries, fitness and some health and health careprofessions, cosmetology, etc.

There are nations where middle or high school students choose to pusue an academic/university track or vocational track, based on their interests and strengths. We need more "college level" vocational programs and high caliber vocational high school electives to elicit the best we can from our rich and diverse population.

Ouch! Don't you know you are writing to liberals, John?

And your point is well taken - and well over-used by those of us who have had the good fortune to end up in the IQ rich gene pool of the successful.

You also, conveniently, offer no solution to helping the disadvantaged students who may be DNA challenged. Don't want to crowd the beaches near the Hamptons with too much color?

Wealthy kids do better because they inherited their parents' IQ? Rather than the fact they inherited an environment with no food scarcity and parents who only work one or two jobs? (Exhibit A being of course Donald Trump?). What bigoted hogwash.

None of this is true, but many believe it nonetheless. Wealthy parents do not have higher IQ's (which is also measured by a standardized test, with roots in the eugenics movement). Case in point? George Bush II.

Calling tests "unfair" just because results tend to correlate highly with family income confuses correlation with causation. Parental income correlates highly with parental IQ, and parental IQ has a high inheritability. Of course there are exceptions, and thank goodness for that.  But it is extremely dishonest for testing critics to keep citing the relationship between parental income and test scores as supposed proof for their theory. In general, wealthy kids do better than poor kids not because they are wealthy but because they have inherited their ability from their parents.

I'm guessing you're not a teacher, because I never met a teacher in my life that says class size doesn't matter.
Public schools are not "bad". Class size matters. Money matters. How do you measure the best 25%?

With all due respect Mr. Myers, you seem to have a generalized understanding of the very complex factors that impact education and high stakes testing.

It's true that public schools across the country in low income communities are under performing. It's also true that schools with 20% poverty or less, rank with the highest performing schools in the world on the international PISA exams.

So, to say that most public schools in this country are bad is an inaccurate generalization. While many public schools in this country are pathetic, many public schools in this country are outstanding.

What are the factors that account for these differences? Simply blaming teachers, and expecting them to compensate for all the challenges associated with poverty is naive.

It's true that schools have focused on testing to an absurd degree, but NCLB does not mandate the constant testing that is going on now. The real problem is that most public schools in this country are bad, and they've compounded the problem through their response to the requirement that they evaluate their teaching. You don't get good test results by constantly testing students. You have to actually teach them.

Ms Ravich doesn't have anything useful to suggest here except vague "focus", but throwing more money at mismanaged schools with weak teachers will accomplish nothing. We know, for example, that class sizes are, within limits, not very important to what students learn. What matters is the skill of the teachers and the engagement of the parents. The best 25% of teachers teach 3 times as much as the worst 25%. But the educational establishment fights tooth and nail against any real attempt to improve the quality of teachers.

Even sadder is the fact that elements of the No Child Left Behind program has become the model for Mexico. After all, the U.S. is the leader, isn't it? Thank you, so much, Diane Ravitch for speaking up.
Wonderful article and highlights the real issue, the issue that no one wants to talk about which is economic disparity and how this effects education. Thank you.
The function of education should be to prepare the population for the modern job market, not to indoctrinate a new generation of liberal.

Common core is what you get when you let business people and philanthropists who have no learning and education background or formal experience developing standards. I call it corporate education and they want the next generation to learn their way so they don't have to take responsibility for training employees anymore. It's just another way the one percentage is pushing the cost down the line.

Especially a foundation whose fiscal strength is based on the success of a growing market in technology. When you can increase your profits by forcing everyone to use your products just to graduate 3rd grade but can claim you are doing it to "improve education" so America's children can compete in technology fields, you have a win-win for yourself.

There's lots of blame to go round, but one thing that stands out to me
is the damage that can be done by a foundation with a lot of cash
which is unaccountable to anybody.

I have been argued out of a not-very-well-informed position (pro Common Core) by a conservative. I appreciate that she did not try to convince me the free market was going to better educate our children. but I have, nonetheless, been persuaded to change my view on this topic...

Most humans are good at one ouror two subjects, and bad at the others. Dragging them to school every day so we can call them failures is not working well.
Students should be allowed to naturally rise to their own level in each subject, so they can be at that sweet spot between boredom and fear. But taking, which used to be based only on English skills, is now "illegal" so any given class will have multiple skill levels from very low to very high. Then the teacher is expected to teach multiple lessons at the same time. It's quite insane.
People that never taught keep making the rules for for teachers. Then when it doesn't work, the teachers are blamed.

"Making the tests harder predictably depresses test scores, creating a sense of failure and hopelessness among young children." It's like blaming wages for the existence of wage-slaves. One doesn't get anywhere by blaming the doctor after learning they have a serious illness. The tests tell us that our students are not learning enough for them to be productive citizens in a modern economy. The patchwork quilt of state standards and content is not helping our children. The Common Core is one remedy that the writer wistfully asks for in the last sentence.

Do the police realize that most of us aren't criminals? We aren't out to hurt them and we aren't interested in getting into arguments with them. I've had dealings with police in my village where, when I ask a question, the officer turns it into an argument. He's the one with the gun, not me. If he thinks that making a question into an argument is law enforcement or is going to prove something he's wrong and he's right. It's not law enforcement but he's proving to me that he can't handle a simple question. Do I want that person on the street patrolling my village? Does he know the difference between someone starting an argument and someone asking a question?

Now, expand that to what has been happening. If the police are treating all of us like potential shooters or they are killing people even after the person says that they are licensed to carry but are reaching for their wallet, they can't expect us to be on their side no matter what color we are. On the other hand, I do understand that they want to go home to their families at the end of their shift. So did the innocent people they shot. There has to be more community policing. In addition, the NRA should not be listened to when it comes to guns. The cops are right here: if they have to worry about everyone carrying a gun because they can, it makes it hard for them to do their job. Last of all, we should not be feeling that our police forces are occupying armies.
So, you hated it?
